column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER TWELVE .
#Text=MARIE TAKES A DESPERATE CHANCE

#Text=Domestic wrecks may be a subject taboo in polite conversation , but Joe De Barr was not excessively polite , and he had , moreover , a very likely hope that Marie would yet choose to regard him with more favor than she had shown in the past .
#Text=He did not chance to see her at once , but as soon as his work would permit he made it a point to meet her .
#Text=He went about it with beautiful directness .
#Text=He made bold to call her up on “ long distance ” from San Francisco , told her that he would be in San Jose that night , and invited her to a show .
#Text=Marie accepted without enthusiasm -- and her listlessness was not lost over forty miles of telephone wire .
#Text=Enough of it seeped to Joe 's ears to make him twist his mustache quite furiously when he came out of the telephone booth .
#Text=If she was still stuck on that fellow Bud , and could n't see anybody else , it was high time she was told a few things about him .
#Text=It was queer how a nice girl like Marie would hang on to some cheap guy like Bud Moore .
#Text=Regular fellows did n't stand any show -- unless they played what cards happened to fall their way .
#Text=Joe , warned by her indifference , set himself very seriously to the problem of playing his cards to the best advantage .

#Text=He went into a flower store -- disdaining the banked loveliness upon the corners -- and bought Marie a dozen great , heavy-headed chrysanthemums , whose color he could not name to save his life , so called them pink and let it go at that .

#Text=They were not pink , and they were not sweet -- Joe held the bunch well away from his protesting olfactory nerves which were not educated to tantalizing odors -- but they were more expensive than roses , and he knew that women raved over them .
#Text=He expected Marie to rave over them , whether she liked them or not .

#Text=Fortified by these , groomed and perfumed and as prosperous looking as a tobacco salesman with a generous expense account may be , he went to San Jose on an early evening train that carried a parlor car in which Joe made himself comfortable .
#Text=He fooled even the sophisticated porter into thinking him a millionaire , wherefore he arrived in a glow of self-esteem , which bred much optimism .
#Text=Marie was impressed -- at least with his assurance and the chrysanthemums , over which she was sufficiently enthusiastic to satisfy even Joe .

#Text=Since he had driven to the house in a hired automobile , he presently had the added satisfaction of handing Marie into the tonneau as though she were a queen entering the royal chariot , and of ordering the driver to take them out around the golf links , since it was still very early .
#Text=Then , settling back with what purported to be a sigh of bliss , he regarded Marie sitting small and still and listless beside him .
#Text=The glow of the chrysanthemums had already faded .
#Text=Marie , with all the girlish prettiness she had ever possessed , and with an added charm that was very elusive and hard to analyze , seemed to have lost all of her old animation .
#Text=Joe tried the weather , and the small gossip of the film world , and a judiciously expurgated sketch of his life since he had last seen her .
#Text=Marie answered him whenever his monologue required answer , but she was unresponsive , uninterested -- bored .
#Text=Joe twisted his mustache , eyed her aslant and took the plunge .
#Text=“ I guess joy-ridin ' kinda calls up old times , ay ? ” he began insidiously .
#Text=“ Maybe I should n't have brought you out for a ride ; maybe it brings back painful memories , as the song goes . ”
#Text=“ Oh , no , ” said Marie spiritlessly .
#Text=“ I do n't see why it should . ”
#Text=“ No ?
#Text=Well , that 's good to hear you say so , girlie .
#Text=I was kinda afraid maybe trouble had hit you hard .
#Text=A sensitive , big-hearted little person like you .
#Text=But if you 've put it all outa your mind , why , that 's where you 're dead right .
#Text=Personally , I was glad to see you saw where you 'd made a mistake , and backed up .
#Text=That takes grit and brains .
#Text=Of course , we all make mistakes -- you was n't to blame -- innocent little kid like you -- ”
#Text=“ Yes , ” said Marie , “ I guess I made a mistake , all right . ”
#Text=“ Sure !
#Text=But you seen it and backed up .
#Text=And a good thing you did .
#Text=Look what he 'd of brought you to by now , if you 'd stuck ! ”
#Text=Marie tilted back her head and looked up at the tall row of eucalyptus trees feathered against the stars .
#Text=“ What ? ” she asked uninterestedly .
#Text=“ Well -- I do n't want to knock , especially a fellow that 's on the toboggan already .
#Text=But I know a little girl that 's aw-fully lucky , and I 'm honest enough to say so . ”
#Text=“ Why ? ” asked Marie obligingly .
#Text=“ Why -- in particular ? ”
#Text=“ Why in particular ? ”
#Text=Joe leaned toward her .
#Text=“ Say , you must of heard how Bud 's going to the dogs .
#Text=If you have n't , I do n't want -- ”
#Text=“ No , I had n't heard , ” said Marie , looking up at the Big Dipper so that her profile , dainty and girlish still , was revealed like a cameo to Joe .
#Text=“ Is he ?
#Text=I love to watch the stars , do n't you ? ”
#Text=“ I love to watch a star , ”
#Text=Joe breathed softly .
#Text=“ So you had n't heard how Bud 's turned out to be a regular souse ?
#Text=Honest , did n't you know it ? ”
#Text=“ No , I did n't know it , ” said Marie boredly .
#Text=“ Has he ? ”
